awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Renewal. Paleontological Reconnaissance of Threatened, Submerged Primate Fossils in a Flooded Cave
awd_abstract_narration:
The fossil record represents one of the few ways that heavily impacted or now-extinct habitats and communities can be reconstructed in order to understand what happened to ecosystems over time. A rich new source of fossils recently has been discovered in large flooded caves in Tsimanampesotse National Park, Madagascar, providing a "snapshot" of a past ecological community.  This fossil "graveyard" contains abundant giant extinct lemurs as well as the skeletal remains of other animal species that co-existed with them. It lies in a location in which only two lemur species survive today, and in a habitat that could not today support the wealth of species that lived there just a few thousand years ago. This project will build upon survey work conducted in 2014, with new collection and preservation of a representative sample of fossils from the flooded caves, and collection of speleothems that can provide a detailed and accurate climate and vegetation history of the region.  Broader impacts include facilitating research on climate change, biodiversity, and population ecology (including of primates) through the resulting skeletal collection, public science outreach through multiple media both in the US and in Madagascar, training of students, and international collaborations.

In this project, the investigators will conduct additional surveys of the caves; collect multiple skeletons for each of several species (including Pachylemur and Megaladapis); and assess intraspecific variation and suitability for ancient DNA, radiocarbon dating, and stable carbon and nitrogen isotope analysis. In addition, speleothems will be collected and analyzed for records of change in climate, precipitation and atmospheric circulation over the past several glacial cycles, and for obtaining dates for the sites. This work will be important for piloting the methods needed to extract information from the fossils themselves, such as interpreting the relative impacts of human agency and climate change on the demise of the megafauna. The caves are in need of immediate attention because they are poorly protected from human and weather disturbances. The environment is sensitive to climatic and geological factors which can rapidly harm fragile specimens or destroy them entirely.

por.por_cntn:
Madagascar is home to one of the world most unique and endangered faunas and floras.  The island experienced a precipitous extinction in the recent past that essentially wiped out its megafauna, which consisted of giant lemurs, elephant birds, horned crocodiles, pygmy hippopotamuses, and many other animals.  However, the fossil record documenting this extinction is limited, so the history, process and causes of megafaunal loss are still debated.   We do not understand how megafaunal loss was influenced by the arrival of people, or how people were impacted once these animals and their habitats were decimated and disappeared.  The goals of this project focused on assessing new opportunities to improve the record by investigating flooded caves in Tsimanampetsotsa National Park which, we discovered, contained large troves of fossils as well as stalagmites that can be dated geochemically and used for reconstructing the ancient environments in which these animals lived. 

We conducted two expeditions and investigated three local submerged caves and one dry, open-air site.  Approximately 500 fossils representing many vertebrate groups were collected, including dozens of specimens from three species of extinct primates, two local extant primate species, two genera of elephant birds, tortoises, flighted birds and many other forms.  Preliminary indications are that we have found a new species of carnivore, a close relative of the endemic living fosa, the largest mammalian carnivore on Madagascar, and of a giant fosa, which was well represented in the caves.  From an ulna of a fossil Megaladapis, a very large and intriguing extinct megafaunal primate, we obtained a date when this individual was alive from carbon remains, and evidence of its plant diet from measurements of stable isotope concentrations. We collected stalagmites from wet and dry caves.  Their dates cover the last 48,000 years, including the critical period when people appear to have arrived in southwestern Madagascar, about 2,900 years ago.  These rocks are important because they can document climate and vegetation history of the region long before human colonization.  Indeed, they extend back much further than the time of the last glacial maximum (~22,000 years ago), and they cover the entire postglacial period, when sea level rose around 130 meters to its current level, and the earth’s climate was powerfully influenced.  And because the dates we obtained include the entire period of human occupation, the stalagmites will offer important insights into the interactions between natural climate change, habitat and biodiversity loss, and landscape alteration by humans due to burning or cultivation.  Evidence of hunting by humans can be gleaned from damage to fossils as well. 

We accomplished several goals relating to the educational outreach mission of the project. The first has policy consequences at local and national levels.  Due to our close collaboration with Madagascar National Parks, the federal entity responsible for the care and preservation of the park system, the Malagasy government is now aware of the patrimonial riches found in these, and surely other that are widely distributed in a vast but little explored geological region of Madagascar where flooded sinkholes are probably common.  Second, with regard to future research and capacity building, all of these materials will be curated at the University of Antananarivo, with our local collaborating partners, and they will be available for research and educational purposes.  In addition to our large American team, two Antananarivo faculty members participated in the fieldwork as did four Malagasy students.  Three of the students have completed Master’s theses while working with us on the project and one who just joined the project has begun her research using new fossils from Tsimanampetsotsa.  One American PhD student one postdocortal student working with us also participated in field work and laboratory analysis of specimens.

Towards the goal of an even wider engagement with the public, we achieved two important aims.  We constructed an underwater paleo-museum, the first of its kind, where properly supervised divers are able to enter a protected, actively researched scientific site and experience first-hand and close-up the natural context in which fossils were deposited and later collected.  We set in place a half-dozen large headstone-like markers inscribed with the names of fossil specimens resting in situ, giving their identifications in Latin, Malagasy, French and English.  We also developed a video, narrated in French, which is now being used by the Madagascar National Parks system as an introduction to the underwater museum and an educational tool.  This video and others are intended to be displayed at the new visitors’ center at Tsimanampetsotsa built in 2016, which will be expanded to include a Paleo-Museum that will provide educational opportunity and materials deriving from our research activities in the park.
